channel.title: BBC News - Home

item.title: Coronavirus: No 10 considering mandatory face masks in shops in England
item.description: Face coverings are already compulsory on transport in a bid to slow the spread of coronavirus.

item.title: Shropshire maternity scandal: Hundreds more cases under review
item.description: Inquiry into care by NHS trust is now assessing about 1,500 cases, the BBC learns.

item.title: EasyJet 'using sickness records to decide job cuts'
item.description: Pilots say the airline will include sick days when assessing job losses - a claim EasyJet rejects.

item.title: Coronavirus lockdown: Parents 'frustrated' by birth registration delays
item.description: Parents say it is frustrating to wait months to register their babies, as councils face large backlogs.

item.title: Ghislaine Maxwell requests bail due to 'significant' coronavirus risk
item.description: The British socialite denies grooming underage girls for the late paedophile Jeffrey Epstein.

item.title: TikTok: Amazon says email asking staff to remove app 'sent in error'
item.description: Earlier, the company had asked staff to remove the TikTok app from phones over "security risks."

item.title: Johnny Depp and Amber Heard: Court hears details of 'violent' marital rows
item.description: A libel case hears the Hollywood actor threw a magnum of champagne at his ex-wife - a claim he denies.

item.title: Hagia Sophia: Turkey turns iconic Istanbul museum into mosque
item.description: President Erdogan reopens Istanbul's Hagia Sophia to Muslim worship, after a court ruling.

item.title: Leicester lockdown factories 'almost doubled staff' during Covid-19
item.description: A whistleblower in Leicester says demand for cheap clothing left workers exposed to Covid-19.

item.title: Dame Vera Lynn: Spitfire flypast marks funeral
item.description: A private funeral is held as friends and fans also pay respects to the Forces' Sweetheart.

item.title: Coronavirus: UK opts out of EU Covid-19 vaccine scheme
item.description: The UK's ambassador to the EU confirms the move, saying the UK would not have a say on decisions.

item.title: France: Bus driver dies after 'attack over face masks' in Bayonne
item.description: The driver in south-western France was set upon by people who reportedly refused to wear face masks.

item.title: Cow rescued by Crammel Linn waterfall near Gilsland
item.description: It is thought a visitor left a gate open allowing the animal to make its way to the water's edge

item.title: 'I left Smile Bank today due to the ongoing outage'
item.description: Smile Bank customers have been unable to access their accounts for days due to an ongoing outage.

item.title: Coronavirus: How libraries provided a lifeline in lockdown
item.description: Libraries kept in touch with customers via various acts of kindness as the coronavirus pandemic hit.

item.title: Fiona Adams, photographer of The Beatles and other rock stars, dies at 84
item.description: Her iconic shot of the band leaping in the air was used on the sleeve of their Twist and Shout EP.

item.title: Naya Rivera: CCTV shows missing Glee star boarding boat
item.description: Naya Rivera has been missing since Wednesday after going on a boat trip with her young son.

item.title: What are the questions for Ghislaine Maxwell?
item.description: The arrest of Jeffrey Epstein's former girlfriend has reignited interest in her and her alleged role in Epstein's abuse of minors.

item.title: Battle of Britain: The schoolgirl who helped design the Spitfire
item.description: Meet the young mathematician who helped design the Spitfire, the iconic aircraft that took part in the Battle of Britain, which started 80 years ago today.

item.title: Quiz of the week: What annoyed Tom Hanks?
item.description: How closely have you been paying attention to what's been going on during the past seven days?

item.title: Sheku Kanneh-Mason returns to a socially distant stage
item.description: Famous for performing at the royal wedding, the cellist has returned to a socially distanced stage.

item.title: Julia Sawalha 'devastated and furious' at Chicken Run sequel 'ageism'
item.description: Actress Julia Sawalha says she was told she sounds "too old" to play the voice of Ginger again.

item.title: Coronavirus: How Mexican cartels are taking advantage of pandemic
item.description: The BBC has secured exclusive access to a cartel trying to win over the poor during the pandemic.

item.title: European hamster added to 'critically endangered' list
item.description: Lemurs, North Atlantic whales and a rare fungus are also new additions to the IUCN's Red List.

item.title: Noah Lyles: 200m 'world record' ruled out... because he only ran 185m
item.description: Noah Lyles briefly appeared to have set an astonishing new 200m world record - beating Usain Bolt's best by 0.29 seconds - before it was revealed he had run 15m short.

item.title: Coronavirus: The British-Pakistani doctors saving lives in both countries
item.description: From his laptop in Essex, Dr Tahir Akhtar is advising Pakistani doctors on treating coronavirus patients.

item.title: Coronavirus: 'Big fat British Asian weddings' forced to slim down
item.description: How has the coronavirus pandemic hit the Asian weddings industry in the UK?

item.title: 'I'm furious that we can't reopen'
item.description: Beauty salons and gyms in England get a date to reopen but some treatments remain blacklisted.

item.title: Coronavirus: How New Zealand went 'hard and early' to beat Covid-19
item.description: What has been the strategy behind New Zealand's Covid-19 success?

item.title: Black Lives Matter: From social media post to global movement
item.description: Black Lives Matter has sparked a hashtag, grass-roots organisations, and a collective of activists.

item.title: What are my rights if I'm stopped and searched?
item.description: Why is the police watchdog launching a review into whether the tactic is discriminatory?

item.title: Mike Skinner: 'Music is genuine chaos'
item.description: The Streets man drops a mixtape of rap duets ahead of a musical film about his recent life as a DJ.

item.title: Rishi Sunak: The 'whatever it takes' chancellor
item.description: He's been dubbed "Dishy Rishi" and "an economic Jedi" but who is the man steering the UK economy?

item.title: Why Hollywood needs computer games tech more than ever
item.description: The same technology that runs computer games is increasingly popular for making films and television.

item.title: Danny Trejo: The actor who went from prisoner to film star
item.description: A new documentary looks at how Danny Trejo left his criminal past to become a film star.

item.title: John Lewis: Watford store closure 'incredibly sad for our town'
item.description: How will the loss of a store giant affect one town's high street?

item.title: Nile Dam row: Egypt and Ethiopia generate heat but no power
item.description: Egypt sees the dam as an existential threat, while Ethiopia sees it as an existential necessity.

item.title: Dowrich and Brathwaite punish England as West Indies take command in first Test
item.description: England are under huge pressure in the opening Test after West Indies take a first-innings lead of 114 on day three in Southampton.

item.title: 'I'm appalled and ashamed' - British Gymnastics boss responds to allegations of abuse in the sport
item.description: British Gymnastics boss Jane Allen says she is "appalled and ashamed" following allegations of abuse within the sport.

item.title: 'How long did it take Klopp?' - Mourinho confident of trophies with Spurs
item.description: Jose Mourinho says he can win trophies at Tottenham and does not think the club need to make a "huge investment" this summer.

item.title: Man City to learn European appeal fate on Monday
item.description: Manchester City will learn on Monday whether their appeal against a two-year ban from European club competitions has been successful.

item.title: Brutal Broad decision looks like a mistake - Agnew
item.description: The argument for leaving Stuart Broad out of the England team is understandable, but it sill looks to be an error, says Jonathan Agnew.

item.title: Fulham beat Cardiff to keep alive automatic promotion hopes
item.description: Goals from Aleksandar Mitrovic and Josh Onomah give Fulham victory over Championship promotion rivals Cardiff City.

item.title: Real two wins from title after beating Alaves
item.description: Real Madrid are two wins away from clinching La Liga title after Karim Benzema and Marco Asensio goals give them victory over Alaves.

item.title: Coronavirus: When can I go to the gym, nail salon, tattoo studio or pool?
item.description: As lockdown eases, more activities will soon be allowed.

item.title: Coronavirus: Can I get travel insurance and what are my travel rights?
item.description: As quarantine rules are relaxed, holidays are back on the agenda but will your insurance cover you?

item.title: Coronavirus: Who should wear a face mask or face covering?
item.description: Face coverings are compulsory on public transport in England and Scotland.

item.title: Will buying my new home be cheaper? And other questions
item.description: Questions about support bubbles, and other coronavirus topics.

item.title: UK social distancing rules - one metre or two metres?
item.description: The UK government is advising people to practise social distancing, but the distance varies depending on where you are.

item.title: Coronavirus vaccine: When will we have one?
item.description: About 200 groups of medical researchers around the world are working on a vaccine for Covid-19.

item.title: Coronavirus: An induction to post-lockdown gyms
item.description: The CEO of Total Fitness, Sophie Lawler, shows how one of her gyms has been adapted for coronavirus.

item.title: Coronavirus: Disease detectives track an invisible culprit
item.description: They're working frantically to stop the pandemic spreading. And sometimes that means some awkward conversations.
